Abecedarium of which only the first four letters remain. The alpha is of the type with a dot on the inside instead 
                    of a horizontal stroke, which is common in the Sicilian context on defixiones 
                    (see ; 
                    , 315 on the 
                    question of alpha variants in archaic Sicilian contexts). The delta also presents a similar ductus, with a dot inside.
                    Agostiniani (2018) provides the apograph of the graffito with an arrow-shaped alpha (type with a bar attached to the 
                    vertex of the letter). However, from an analysis of the photograph reported in Arena IGASM 2[2] 92 (pl. 27.3) the alpha appears 
                    to be of the type with a dot in the centre, while the mark interpreted as the first bar of the alpha appears to be an 
                    encrustation on the vessel.
                    The reason for the difference of the ductus of alpha is to be found in the particular nature of the text, the alphabetarium, which presents 
                    the 'model' types of the local alphabet. It should also be noted that, without the possibility of tracing the archaeological 
                    context in this case, it is difficult to date the document on a palaeographic basis.
                    On other abecedaries found in Sicily on ceramics see Tribulato 2017 (and on this document in particular p. 119).

Facsimile Images

1ΑΒΓΔ[---]

Apparatus criticus

  • Text after Arena (IGASM 2)

English translation

Italian translation

commentary

Abecedarium of which only the first four letters remain. The alpha is of the type with a dot on the inside instead of a horizontal stroke, which is common in the Sicilian context on defixiones (see Brugnone 1978; Tribulato, Mignosa 2021, 315 on the question of alpha variants in archaic Sicilian contexts). The delta also presents a similar ductus, with a dot inside. Agostiniani (2018) provides the apograph of the graffito with an arrow-shaped alpha (type with a bar attached to the vertex of the letter). However, from an analysis of the photograph reported in Arena IGASM 2[2] 92 (pl. 27.3) the alpha appears to be of the type with a dot in the centre, while the mark interpreted as the first bar of the alpha appears to be an encrustation on the vessel. The reason for the difference of the ductus of alpha is to be found in the particular nature of the text, the alphabetarium, which presents the 'model' types of the local alphabet. It should also be noted that, without the possibility of tracing the archaeological context in this case, it is difficult to date the document on a palaeographic basis. On other abecedaries found in Sicily on ceramics see Tribulato 2017 (and on this document in particular p. 119).

1ΑΒΓΔ[---]

commentary

Abecedarium of which only the first four letters remain. The alpha is of the type with a dot on the inside instead of a horizontal stroke, which is common in the Sicilian context on defixiones (see Brugnone 1978; Tribulato, Mignosa 2021, 315 on the question of alpha variants in archaic Sicilian contexts). The delta also presents a similar ductus, with a dot inside. Agostiniani (2018) provides the apograph of the graffito with an arrow-shaped alpha (type with a bar attached to the vertex of the letter). However, from an analysis of the photograph reported in Arena IGASM 2[2] 92 (pl. 27.3) the alpha appears to be of the type with a dot in the centre, while the mark interpreted as the first bar of the alpha appears to be an encrustation on the vessel. The reason for the difference of the ductus of alpha is to be found in the particular nature of the text, the alphabetarium, which presents the 'model' types of the local alphabet. It should also be noted that, without the possibility of tracing the archaeological context in this case, it is difficult to date the document on a palaeographic basis. On other abecedaries found in Sicily on ceramics see Tribulato 2017 (and on this document in particular p. 119).
